{"title":"Section 2, Page 43","subjec":{},"descri":{},"creato":{},"publis":{},"date":{},"year":{},"format":{},"reposi":{},"collec":{},"reposa":{},"rights":{},"digitb":{},"langua":{},"topics":{},"cite":{},"notes":{},"notesa":{},"source":{},"box":{},"folder":{},"identi":{},"relati":{},"findin":{},"catalo":{},"type":{},"full":"43
(.a„ie forward and addressed the convention. Mr.
Sever drew an exciting picture of the advantages of
railroads and other internal improvements, on the
prosperity of a state or people, in a speech of telling power.
On motion of John E. King, of St. Landry, seconded by E. II. Martin, it was
Resolved, That the thanks of the respective delegations
assembled in convention, be and are hereby tendered to the
committee of arrangements, and the citizens of New Orleans generally, for the splendid accomodations which they
have provided, and for the uniform kindness and courtesy
with which they have received and entertained the delegates
from the country parishes.
On motion of Judge Moore, seconded by M. M.
Cohen, it was
Resolved, That the thanks of the convention be and are
hereby tendered to the worthy President, for the able manner in which he has ruled and regulated the discussions and
deliberations of this convention ; and that the thanks of the
convention be also tendered to the Secretaries officiating.
The President replied, in beautiful terms, to the
vote of thanks just tendered, and so warmly and
enthusiastically adopted. He said, the unexpected
and unmerited compliment you have just paid me,
and the indulgence you have so kindly extended, has
taken me by surprize, and so operated on my ke\-
ings, as to deprive me of the power of expressing
myself in language suitable to such an occasion.—
Coming, as it does, from a convention composed of
